com.pump.swing

Class ContainerProperties

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Dictionary<K,V>
      • java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>
        • java.util.Properties
          • com.pump.swing.ContainerProperties
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.util.Map<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>

    public class ContainerProperties
extends java.util.Properties
    This helps serialize and deserialize simple UIs based on the names of components. For example, if you have a selected JCheckBox with the name "is-preloaded", then after calling catalog(Container) on any parent of that JCheckBox this ContainerProperties will include "is-preloaded=true". Similarly when you call #install(Container, UncaughtExceptionHandler) it will parse that value and set the UI accordingly.

    This only supports a small set of data types in JToggleButtons, JTextComponents, JComboBoxes and JLists: primitives, Strings, BigDecimals, BigIntegers, and Files. It's possible this object can serialize values but it won't be able to deserialize them later.

    This is a quick and light tool intended to help with settings, but it is not a good solution for complex (or crucial) saved data.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      static java.lang.String KEY_PROPERTY_NAME

                                   java.lang.Class<?> componentType,

        Convert a String representation to an Object
        Parameters:
        toStringValue - the serialized String value
        componentType - the type of object that is returned.
        handler - a handler to notify if something goes wrong
        Returns:
        the Object represented by the argument String.

      • install

        public void install(java.awt.Container container,
                    java.lang.Thread.UncaughtExceptionHandler handler)
        Install these properties on a Container's descendants.
        Parameters:
        container - Configure all the components in the argument that match properties stored in this ContainerProperties.
        handler - this will be notified as exceptions come up. If this is null, then a default exception handler is used that quietly prints messages to System.err but continues to iterate over all possible components.
